message_1:
A math teacher wants to know if her students study consistently throughout the semester or only before exams. She randomly selects 10 students from her class and records the number of hours each student studies per week. The data is shown below:

5, 3, 7, 6, 8, 2, 4, 6, 10, 1

Using inductive logic, what percentage of the students studied consistently throughout the semester (i.e. studied the same number of hours per week) based on the data?
message_2:
To determine the percentage of students who studied consistently throughout the semester, we need to first identify the students who studied the same number of hours per week. Since the data provided does not show the weekly study hours for each student throughout the semester, we cannot directly determine which students studied consistently.

However, we can use inductive logic to make an educated guess based on the data provided. We can assume that students who studied a similar number of hours per week are more likely to have studied consistently. In this case, we can look for students with similar study hours.

The data is:

5, 3, 7, 6, 8, 2, 4, 6, 10, 1

We can group the students with similar study hours:

- 1, 2, 3, 4 (4 students)
- 5, 6, 6, 7 (4 students)
- 8, 10 (2 students)

Based on this grouping, we can assume that the middle group (5, 6, 6, 7) is more likely to have studied consistently, as their study hours are closer together. This group represents 4 out of the 10 students.

Therefore, we can estimate that 40% (4 out of 10 students) of the students studied consistently throughout the semester based on the data provided. However, it is important to note that this is an estimation using inductive logic and not a definitive conclusion.
